üåüThe "platform" role at venture capital funds is the newer, shiny role that has been gaining more attention as firms look to differentiate themselves and provide deep strategic advantages to their portfolio. As a relatively newer role, the responsibilities can often be misunderstood and may vary drastically from fund to fund. For some, the role may focus more on strategic corporate partnerships; some may focus more on building a media machine; and some may focus more on relationships with downstream investors. Ultimately, of the three main pillars of a venture fund (sourcing, diligence, support), platform roles focus almost entirely on the support side of the portfolio. Tentative Outline: - What is Platform? - Investor Relations & Downstream Fundraising - GTM Support - Portfolio Company Needs - Events & Community Building - Operations - Portfolio Hiring - How Platform Varies from Fund to Fund - How to Break into a Platform Role Over the next couple of weeks, I will be interviewing folks in these roles and synthesizing the findings into a playbook designed to demystify the role and provide more context into how the responsibilities can vary from fund to fund. This will be a follow-up to my previously published fundraising playbook for Emerging Managers: https://lnkd.in/gqM7jyuS If you're curious about the role, feel free to drop some questions for me to address. If you or someone you know are currently in a platform role and are interested in being added to the list of interviewees, feel free to reach out as well!

üìë The team at AlphaQ Venture Capital published a guide recently for Emerging #VCs fundraising. üëá Here are 10 takeaways for Venture Capital managers from their report 1Ô∏è‚É£ Understanding Investor Types: It's crucial to recognise different investor types, such as HNWIs, Family Offices, Corporates, and Institutional Investors. Each has different (and often unique) motivations and behaviours. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Investor Approaches: Investors follow either Opportunistic (people-driven) or Strategic (mandate-driven) approaches. Understanding them helps in tailoring your pitches and strategies. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Investment Strategy & USP: Developing a clear strategy and USP is essential for differentiating your fund from competitors and appealing to specific investor needs. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Building Relationships: Building genuine and long-term relationships with investors is crucial, as VC investments often involve long-term commitments. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Effective Communication: Consistent and transparent communication is key when building trust with investors. This can include regular updates on fund performance and strategies. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Content Creation: Creating engaging and informative content is vital for standing out in a crowded market. This content can showcase the fund‚Äôs strategies, market insights, and portfolio highlights... like this LinkedIn post üíÅ‚ôÇÔ∏è 7Ô∏è‚É£ Investor Education: For funds focusing on emerging markets or innovative sectors, educating investors about the investment thesis and market potential is important. 8Ô∏è‚É£ Pipeline Management: Efficient management of your investor pipeline from lead generation to deal closing is vital. This includes developing a target database, enriching investor profiles, and generating qualified leads. 9Ô∏è‚É£ Urgency and Momentum: Similarly to raising funds for a startup, creating FOMO, setting closing deadlines, and highlighting early commitments from respected investors can help speed up the fundraising process. üîü Feedback and Improvement: Soliciting and using feedback from potential investors is crucial for continuous improvement and relationship building, especially for emerging managers.

Venture capital offers a unique avenue for investment that can be appealing for several reasons. Firstly, it provides an opportunity to invest in early-stage companies with high growth potential. While the risk is higher, so is the potential return on investment. Additionally, venture capital allows investors to diversify their portfolios beyond traditional asset classes like stocks and bonds. This diversification can be a key strategy for managing risk and enhancing overall portfolio performance. Investing in VC funds also provides a chance to be part of innovative and cutting-edge industries. You get a front-row seat to the development of groundbreaking technologies and ideas that can shape the future. If you are curious about what it would look like to invest in Xcellerant Ventures or want to talk about the current VC landscape, please reach out to our GP, Douglas Sylvester, on LinkedIn or at dyslvester@xcellerantventures.com. While we may be a newer fund, there are many benefits in investing in our fund based on leadership alone: 1. The potential to form strong GP-LP relationships early that are sustainable over the long term 2. Access to unique deal flow and strong domain experience 3. Access to diverse strategies (minority or women-owned firms) 4. Unique fund types, geographic focus, and industry/sector focus 5. First-time funds can present compelling opportunities for limited partners looking to add an additional mix of managers to their illiquid allocation. #venturecapital #investing #limitedpartners #vc #alternativeinvestments

If you are just starting to angel invest or switching careers to venture capital... Here's a quick guide to some of the most common VC acronyms: AUM: Assets Under Management - The total value of investments a VC firm manages. LP: Limited Partner - Investors who provide capital to VC funds. IRR: Internal Rate of Return - A metric used to measure the profitability of an investment. MVP: Minimum Viable Product - The most basic version of a product that can be released to market. ARR: Annual Recurring Revenue - The amount of revenue a company expects to repeat annually. DD: Due Diligence - The process of investigating a potential investment opportunity. PMF: Product-Market Fit - When a company's product satisfies a strong market demand. TAM: Total Addressable Market - The total potential market size for a product or service. ROI: Return on Investment - The profit generated from an investment relative to its cost. NDA: Non-Disclosure Agreement - A legal contract to keep sensitive information confidential. SAFE: Simple Agreement for Future Equity - A type of investment agreement often used in early-stage funding. DPI: Distributions to Paid-In Capital - The amount of capital returned to investors divided by the amount of capital paid in. There are a lot more but this is a great starting point. #vc #venturecapital #angelinvesting #career #investor

2023 saw a dip in global venture capital (VC) and initial public offering (IPO) activity. Looking to 2024, VC funding is expected to hold steady with investors tightening their underwriting. IPOs are on the rise as companies, previously cautious in 2023, now eye public offerings. Successful clinical trials will continue to sway investment decisions in both VC and IPO domains. 2023 witnessed a surge in mergers and acquisitions (M&A), a trend set to continue in 2024 as companies seek innovative strategies for faster product launches and increased efficiency. In 2024, the U.S. life sciences commercial real estate (CRE) sector faces a pivotal year, offering a tenant-friendly market due to softening fundamentals and a surge in new inventory.
